conclusion: To find the work done by the gas from state B to state C, we need to analyze the p-V diagram and use the concept of work done by a gas in an ideal gas law process.
State A: 27 °C, 1 atm (101.3 kPa); State B: 2 atm (202.6 kPa); State C: 3 atm (303.9 kPa)
The work done by a gas in an ideal gas law process is given by the formula: W = ∫ p dV
The work done from state B to state C is the difference in the work done from state A to state B and state B to state C.
From state A to state B, the gas expands from 1 atm to 2 atm.
The change in volume from state A to state B is ΔV = V_B - V_A = 1 x 10^-3 m^3
The work done from state A to state B is W_AB = p_A ΔV = 101.3 J
From state B to state C, the gas expands from 2 atm to 3 atm.
The change in volume from state B to state C is ΔV = V_C - V_B = 1 x 10^-3 m^3
The work done from state B to state C is W_BC = p_B ΔV = 202.6 J
The total work done by the gas from state B to state C is W_total = W_BC - W_AB = 101.3 J
Therefore, the work done by the gas from state B to state C is 101.3 J.
